awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Time Matters - A Comparison of Diatom 14C and Thermochemical 14C Dating Methods in Sediment Records of Ice Retreat from the East and West Antarctic Margins
awd_abstract_narration:
The seafloor is covered in a thick layer of mud called sediment. Ocean sediment accumulates over time as debris from adjacent continents, atmospheric dust, and the skeletons of microscopic marine organisms settle on the seafloor.  As sediment accumulates in the oceans surrounding Antarctica, it records past environmental conditions including ice sheet behavior as the ice retreated following the last Ice Age.  Scientists use a variety of chemical analyses to determine how long ago sediments were deposited on the seafloor, and are therefore able to relate ice sheet behavior to specific periods of time in the past.  However, it has been challenging to determine the age of sediments around Antarctica, because the sediments often lack material that can be dated by conventional methods. In this project, researchers from the University of South Florida and the University of Washington will test newly developed methods for dating Antarctic continental margin sediments and refine the timing of ice retreat since the last Ice Age. Ultimately, accurately assessing the timing of Antarctic ice retreat from marine sediment cores will enable a better understanding of Earth's response to changing environmental conditions.  This project includes training of a Ph.D. student at the University of South Florida, producing videos for educators in the state of Florida, and public outreach at the annual St. Petersburg Science Fest.  

Antarctic margin sediments are difficult to accurately date because the calcium carbonate shells of marine organisms that are typically used throughout the world's oceans to date sediments are not often preserved. In this project, researchers from the University of South Florida and the University of Washington focus on two tasks:  1) separating less thermochemically-stable carbon (more likely derived from carbon with an age equal to the depositional age of the sediment) from more stable carbon (more likely eroded from the adjacent continent by glacial erosion); and 2) isolating specific organic compounds from marine diatoms, which are primary producers in the Southern Ocean.  The work will use previously collected samples in sediment cores obtained from the Southern Ocean seafloor.  At each depth horizon in each sediment core studied, scientists will use established radiocarbon methods to date the carbon derived from each of these new preparation techniques. This work will determine the best practices in radiocarbon dating of carbonate-poor Antarctic sediments, which will ultimately improve understanding of the factors influencing past and future Antarctic ice sheet behavior.

por.por_cntn:
The impact of this project was that it allowed an investigation into the most fundamental aspect of geology - how to tell time in the sedimentary and rock records. Telling time is at the root of any geological study, but it is not always easy. In the Antarctic margin, which saw expanse and retreat of glaciers during the Earth's natural swings between ice ages, sediment chronology is difficult despite the important records of ice advance and retreat that the sediments hold.

For the time period of the last deglaciation, which happened from the end of maximum glacier coverage about 20,000 years ago until about 11,700 years ago, the radiocarbon chronometer with a half life of 5,730 years is well suited. To date a sedimentary record, carbon from the shells of organisms, both microscopic and large enough to see with the eye, as well as organic carbon from the tissues of these organisms can be dated. These organisms generally live in the water over a short period of time and therefore their deaths mark the age of sedimentation. In Antarctic sediments from close to the coast, the shells are often dissolved and cannot be dated. Researchers have used the organic carbon to date the sediments, but in addition to carbon from marine organisms, there can be carbon from eroded rocks that gives the appearance of an older age to the sample. Recently, scientists have developed tools to either extract and date particular chemicals that are associate more with marine life than ancient rocks and to heat a sample to separate the younger, more reactive carbon from the older carbon. Both methods (chemical extraction and thermochemical extraction, respectively) have produced better ages in some cases. But the question of which method is best to use in what types of sediments rises as a result. 

We set out to test a simple hypothesis: that various types of radiocarbon dating (chemical extraction, thermochemical extraction, bulk organic matter, and calcium carbonate microfossil) would produce the same ages from any one sediment core depth in Antartic margin sediment. There was already ample evidence that this hypothesis is not supported; both chemical extraction (compound specific) and thermochemical extraction (ramped pyrox) dating had shown improved, and different, results than bulk organic matter dating from sediments where there was no option for a microfossil date. The analysis of what types of sediment, where, and why this hypothesis is not supported was the aim of this project. Our results will allow future expedition leaders to know what type of dating to apply to Antarctic margin sediment cores once the sediment is described, rendering a a better understanding of deglacial and other processes from around Antarctica.

Perhaps surprisingly, our results did show some support for our hypothesis in systems where sedimentation was rapid. Areas of ponded sediment, where sediment fills in natural depressions, showed the least variability between dating techniques. This is important to know; a large proportion of the literature centers on bulk organic matter dates from Antarctic margin sediment and these data have certainly guided our understanding of natural climate change around Antarctica during the last deglaciation. However, sedimentation rate was not the key variable in areas where the hypothesis was refuted. In these areas, one of the key variables was the types of diatoms, a microscopic photosynthesizing organism that lives in surface oceans.  The mix of species, called an assemblage, holds implications for both diatom life history (seasonality, water depth, etc.) and depositional history (spore formation, mat formation, etc.). By studying the assemblages, the average grain size of the sediments, and amount of diatoms, we saw patterns to explain when chemically-extracted organic matter ages are older than thermochemically-extracted organic matter ages. Importantly, whereas not all of these analyses can be done quickly aboard a ship, our work will show that shipboard sediment descriptions and smear slides can go a long way to deciding how to best date margin sediment from Antarctica.

This work will be presented in an April 2024 dissertation defense and subsequently published. As mentioned above, these techniques to apply different dating approaches are also being used by another Ph.D. student who will likely publish results in the coming years based on this work.
